instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message:
The user said that the system was working fine and suddenly one day its backlight was missing. I can see the laptop has been already opened by someone. Even the display assembly also opened. I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> display spare for testing, Will it work?. I don't have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> working display to confirm the failure. 
I couldn't find the backlight flex cable broken physically.
Is there a way I can confirm the issue, I don't know whether it is the problem with the display or motherboard?  
I can see the display image if I use a mobile flash light.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message:
What is the exact backlight voltage (LCD connected)?

If you want to test with other screen, be sure the video connector has the same layout.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message:
Schematic/boardview available, probably already posted on the forum.
Post the voltage at <CAPACITOR>C8466</CAPACITOR> (or other cap in the same row), with machine on and lid opened.

threads.message: Sometimes I can see even higher voltage (Upto 12V) But not consistent, Keep reducing

threads.message: <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> stays high 12V ,<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is 5.1V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message:
Did you measure with LCD connected (above mentioned)?

You can use <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> screen assembly for test.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message: Yes, Confirmed that it is not a displayed problem, Even with the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> display it has the same behavior, No backlight. Either the boost circuitry not working or it is the flex cable between the display and Motherboard?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground on backlight output.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message: Diode mode - 1.150V with and without LCD

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message:
Is that reading with red probe at ground?
Compare value with a good board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message: I think I have to remove the board and check the voltages on <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message:
If you catched 12V at backlight output, means that is trying to start at least.
Check all traces and solders in backlight cicuitry.
Change the small video cable from MLB; need to discard it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message:
The feedback resistor was corroted , Now backlight is working .
I have also seen L8504 was burned , Since the <CHIP>U5610</CHIP> not equipped I have just removed that inductor, Do you know whats the purpose of this circuitry ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message:
L8504 powers up webcam and ALS, through LCD connector.
If got burnt, there could be a short in the flex inside LCD assembly.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message: Does it mean that I have to change the screen first to fix the issue ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message: If you do not solder L8504, no webcam function, nor ALS.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC3214, No display backlight
threads.message: Yes ,I have measured the impedance it was high, So kept the ferrite bead back, and it's working now. Thanks
